These druids meet within sacred circles of trees or standing stones to whisper primal secrets in Druidic. The circle’s wisest members preside as the chief priests of communities that hold to the Old Faith and serve as advisors to the rulers of those folk. reference_contexts: Druid Class Features As a druid, you gain the following class features. Hit Points Hit Dice: 1d8 per druid level Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per druid level after 1st Proficiencies Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields (druids will not wear armor or use shields made of metal) Weapons: Clubs, daggers, darts, javelins, maces, quarterstaffs, scimitars, sickles, slings, spears Tools: Herbalism kit Saving Throws: Intelligence, Wisdom Skills: Choose two from Arcana, Animal Handling, Insight, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Religion, and Survival Equipment You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background: •(a) a wooden shield or (b) any simple weapon •(a) a scimitar or (b) any simple melee weapon •Leather armor, an explorer’s pack, and a druidic focus The Druid Proficiency Cantrips -Spell Slots per Spell Level- Level Bonus Features Known 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th 1st +2 Druidic, Spellcasting 2 2 - - - - - - - - 2nd +2 plague, scrying Land’s Stride Starting at 6th level, moving through nonmagical difficult terrain costs you no extra movement. You can also pass through nonmagical plants without being slowed by them and without taking damage from them if they have thorns, spines, or a similar hazard. In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against plants that are magically created or manipulated to impede movement, such those created by the entanglespell. Nature’s Ward When you reach 10th level, you can’t be charmed or frightened by elementals or fey, and you are immune to poison and disease. Nature’s Sanctuary When you reach 14th level, creatures of the natural world sense your connection to nature and become hesitant to attack you. When a beast or plant creature attacks you, that creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your druid spell save DC.On a failed save, the creature must choose a different target, or the attack automatically misses.On a successful save, the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours.The creature is aware of this effect before it makes its attack against you. Sacred Plants and Wood A druid holds certain plants to be sacred, particularly alder, ash, birch, elder, hazel, holly, juniper, mistletoe, oak, rowan, willow, and yew. Druids often use such plants as part of a spellcasting focus, incorporating lengths of oak or yew or sprigs of mistletoe. Similarly, a druid uses such woods to make other objects, such as weapons and shields. Yew is associated with death and rebirth, so weapon handles for scimitars or sickles might be fashioned from it. Ash is associated with life and oak with strength. These woods make excellent hafts or whole weapons, such as clubs or quarterstaffs, as well as shields. Alder is associated with air, and it might be used for thrown weapons, such as darts or javelins. Druids from regions that lack the plants described here have chosen other plants to take on similar uses. For instance, a druid of a desert region might value the yucca tree and cactus plants. Druids and the Gods Some druids venerate the forces of nature themselves, but most druids are devoted to one of the many nature deities worshiped in the multiverse (the lists of gods in appendix PH--B include many such deities). The worship of these deities is often considered a more ancient tradition than the faiths of clerics and urbanized peoples.

reference: According to the equipment section of the druid class features, a druid starts with a "druidic focus" as part of their equipment (see the list that includes a wooden shield or any simple weapon, a scimitar or any simple melee weapon, leather armor, an explorer’s pack, and a druidic focus).  The spellcasting section states that a druid can use a druidic focus as a spellcasting focus for their druid spells (see the paragraph that reads, "You can use a druidic focus (see “Equipment”) as a spellcasting focus for your druid spells").  This focus is not limited to metal; druids will not wear armor or use shields made of metal, and the focus is typically made from natural materials such as oak, yew, alder, or other sacred woods.  The druidic focus also ties into the druidic language, which is the secret language of druids; it can be used to leave hidden messages that only those who know the language can decipher.  Thus, the druidic focus serves both as a physical tool for spellcasting and as a symbolic link to the druidic language and the sacred plants that druids use to craft their tools.

Hit Points Hit Dice: 1d8 per druid level Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per druid level after 1st Proficiencies Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields (druids will not wear armor or use shields made of metal) Weapons: Clubs, daggers, darts, javelins, maces, quarterstaffs, scimitars, sickles, slings, spears Tools: Herbalism kit Saving Throws: Intelligence, Wisdom Skills: Choose two from Arcana, Animal Handling, Insight, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Religion, and Survival Equipment You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background: •(a) a wooden shield or (b) any simple weapon •(a) a scimitar or (b) any simple melee weapon •Leather armor, an explorer’s pack, and a druidic focus The Druid Proficiency Cantrips -Spell Slots per Spell Level- Level Bonus Features Known 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th 1st +2 Druidic, Spellcasting 2 2 - - - - - - - - 2nd +2 plague, scrying Land’s Stride Starting at 6th level, moving through nonmagical difficult terrain costs you no extra movement. You can also pass through nonmagical plants without being slowed by them and without taking damage from them if they have thorns, spines, or a similar hazard. In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against plants that are magically created or manipulated to impede movement, such those created by the entanglespell. Nature’s Ward When you reach 10th level, you can’t be charmed or frightened by elementals or fey, and you are immune to poison and disease. Nature’s Sanctuary When you reach 14th level, creatures of the natural world sense your connection to nature and become hesitant to attack you. When a beast or plant creature attacks you, that creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your druid spell save DC.On a failed save, the creature must choose a different target, or the attack automatically misses.On a successful save, the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours.The creature is aware of this effect before it makes its attack against you. Sacred Plants and Wood A druid holds certain plants to be sacred, particularly alder, ash, birch, elder, hazel, holly, juniper, mistletoe, oak, rowan, willow, and yew. Druids often use such plants as part of a spellcasting focus, incorporating lengths of oak or yew or sprigs of mistletoe. Similarly, a druid uses such woods to make other objects, such as weapons and shields. Yew is associated with death and rebirth, so weapon handles for scimitars or sickles might be fashioned from it. Ash is associated with life and oak with strength. These woods make excellent hafts or whole weapons, such as clubs or quarterstaffs, as well as shields. Alder is associated with air, and it might be used for thrown weapons, such as darts or javelins. Druids from regions that lack the plants described here have chosen other plants to take on similar uses. For instance, a druid of a desert region might value the yucca tree and cactus plants. Druids and the Gods Some druids venerate the forces of nature themselves, but most druids are devoted to one of the many nature deities worshiped in the multiverse (the lists of gods in appendix PH--B include many such deities). The worship of these deities is often considered a more ancient tradition than the faiths of clerics and urbanized peoples.

According to the Wild Shape rules in the first context, when a Druid reverts to normal form they return to the hit points they had before transforming. If the revert is caused by dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to the normal form. For example, taking 10 damage in animal form with only 1 hit point left causes a revert and the Druid takes 9 damage in normal form; as long as that excess damage does not reduce the normal form to 0, the Druid is not knocked unconscious. The rules also state that while in beast form the Druid cannot cast spells that require hands or speech, but they can still perform somatic and verbal components of spells they have already cast, and they retain any class features that are physically possible in the new form. Equipment handling is governed by the choice to let it fall, merge, or be worn. Worn equipment functions normally, but the GM decides if it is practical for the beast. Equipment that cannot be worn must either fall or merge; merged equipment has no effect until the Druid leaves the beast form.

At 18th level, the Druid gains the Beast Spells feature, allowing them to cast many druid spells while in any shape. They can perform somatic and verbal components in beast form, but cannot provide material components. At 20th level, the Archdruid feature lets the Druid ignore verbal and somatic components of druid spells, and also ignore material components that lack a cost and are not consumed. This means that Circle of the Land spells that normally require verbal or somatic components can be cast in beast form without those components, and material components that are free or non‑consumable can also be ignored. However, if a spell requires a material component that has a cost or is consumed, the Druid would still need to provide it, unless the equipment that would normally supply it is merged and therefore unavailable.

The Druid’s class features such as Land’s Stride, Nature’s Ward, and Nature’s Sanctuary are retained while in beast form as long as the new form is physically capable of using them. For example, Land’s Stride allows the Druid to move through non‑magical difficult terrain without extra cost, and Nature’s Ward provides immunity to poison and disease, both of which remain active in beast form. The equipment choices made at character creation—such as a wooden shield, a simple weapon, leather armor, an explorer’s pack, and a druidic focus—are subject to the same merge/fall/wear rules, so a druidic focus that is merged into the beast form cannot be used to provide a material component until the Druid leaves the form.

In summary, Wild Shape affects hit point recovery by restoring the pre‑transform hit points and carrying over excess damage, limits spellcasting to somatic and verbal components unless the Druid is an Archdruid, and requires careful consideration of equipment handling to determine whether material components can be supplied while in beast form. The Circle of the Land spells are fully usable in beast form under these rules, with component requirements waived at 20th level, but the availability of material components still depends on whether the necessary equipment is worn or merged.

At 18th level a druid gains the Beast Spells feature, which lets them cast many druid spells while in any Wild Shape. The rules state that while in beast form the druid can perform the somatic and verbal components of a spell, but cannot provide material components. This means that a druid can still speak Druidic (the secret language) while in beast form, because speaking is a verbal action. The Druidic language rules say that anyone who knows Druidic automatically spots a hidden message written in it, and others can detect its presence with a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check but cannot decipher it without magic. Thus, a druid can leave a hidden Druidic message in beast form, and other druids will spot it instantly, while non‑druids will only notice the presence.

Equipment rules for Wild Shape say that a druid may choose whether equipment falls, merges, or is worn. Equipment that merges has no effect until the druid leaves the form. Because the druid’s equipment does not change size or shape to match the beast, any gear that the beast cannot wear must either fall or merge. Therefore, while in beast form a druid cannot use a weapon or armor that the beast cannot physically hold or wear, even though the druid retains the ability to cast spells.

The ability to speak Druidic is not limited by the beast form; the rules explicitly allow verbal components in beast form. However, the druid cannot provide material components unless the beast form can hold them. The Archdruid feature at 20th level removes the need for verbal and somatic components entirely, so a 20th‑level druid could cast a spell in beast form without speaking Druidic at all.

In summary: a druid can speak Druidic while Wild‑shaped, can leave hidden messages that other druids spot instantly, can cast spells that require verbal components (but not material components unless the beast can hold them), and equipment that merges with the beast form is inert until the druid reverts.
